name: Before the (Space)war: Video game and video art history in the 1940s and 50s
description: Time-based media art has long served as a moniker for how scholars and institutions have placed video games in the historical lexicon, much like their sibling, video art. The 1960s is often cited as the origin point of both video art and video games, but is this really the case? Afterall, new technologies are iterative as are the moments of inspiration they create. This panel will explore the very earliest origins of both before the days of Nam June Paik, Ralph Baer, and MIT’s Spacewar and how that history challenges notions and definitions of “firsts” and how we think about them.

name: Enders, Halo, Neuromancer's and Witcher's, oh my! - How Speculative Fiction and Gaming have shaped each other
description:
There’s always been a relationship between speculative fiction and gaming, to the point Bradbury and Clarke were writing stories about gaming decades before the Atari. It didn't take long for gaming to pull from genre fiction - Dune, Discworld, Shannara and Pern were adapted as games long before they were to screen, and some, like the adaptation of I Have No Mouth, and I Must Scream, were proof of gaming’s potential.

Novels from Ender's Game to Snow Crash proved prophetic about the growing impact of gaming. Some of gaming’s biggest franchises, even when not adapting directly, were clearly influenced by it - most famously a riff on Larry Niven's Ringworld by the name of Halo.
 
Today, we're seeing a new trend - books heavily influenced by gaming, as well as some of the biggest titles in the world, such as The Witcher and Metro, adapting recent works of the genre. Together, they offer as much as they always have - for game developers, stories to pull from, for writers, new ways to see their work adapted, and for gamers and readers alike, countless new worlds to explore. 

There will be prize giveaways, so stay sharp, and come ready!

name: Making (Outer) Space to Play: A Cosmic History of the American Video Game
description:
Space-themed video games have enjoyed perennial popularity in the American video game industry. They are present in “big moments” in the history of the medium, from the development and proliferation of SpaceWar! to Atari’s origins with Nolan Bushnell’s Computer Space to the global phenomenon of Taito’s Space Invaders. But what accounts for the space theme’s popularity?
Drawing upon the academic fields of Science and Technology Studies, the History of Computing, and the History of Science Fiction, this presentation offers three reasons why the space theme was so valuable to the nascent American video game industry: (1) it was a vehicle for technical experimentation, (2) it prompted organizational innovation, and (3) it drove the attraction of a base of players for this new medium.
In covering case studies such as SpaceWar!’s prehistory, game pioneer Danielle Bunten Berry’s mission to build a better multiplayer game with M.U.L.E., and the proposed inclusion in Atari’s 1983 Star Wars arcade cabinet of technology to awaken powers of extrasensory perception in the American public, this presentation will show why space mattered to an industry in its adolescence and why studying its popularity matters to the history of a beloved technology of play: the video game.

name: Environmental Storytelling & Show Don’t Tell: How I Learned to Write through Playing Video Games
description: The popular saying goes: “A picture’s worth a thousand words.” With the rapid developments in technology, our storytelling is changing to not just be on the page, but through movies, television, and video games--highly visual mediums. Through the power of images, we can convey a whole narrative in a short space. Games like Deus Ex: Mankind Divided and Gone Home use environmental storytelling to give us pieces of characters’ lives. In this workshop, we’ll discuss examples of games that tell stories through objects, and go into our own writing exercises that can be used to develop the environments in our own stories, campaigns, or games.

name: Ping Me: High-Performance Communication in Competitive Gaming
description:
What if I told you that you can learn how the best FPS teams call out enemy locations, how to finally get the attention of your party healer, how to negotiate for that raise you’ve wanted, and maybe even how to get your drive-thru order right every time?
High-Performance Communication is often an underappreciated aspect not just in team-based games, but also in large parts of daily life. Luckily, there is a science behind it to explain how communication works, and when it doesn’t work, why. 
Almost all communication can be simplified down to a single representative model, and we will see how each element of it can make the difference between an exhilarating victory or a crushing defeat (or missing that side order of fries). From there, we’ll cover some specific strategies of how to improve communication with and within your team to gain a competitive edge including an interactive exercise anyone in the audience can participate in. Do you think you can talk your way into the winners circle? Come find out!

name: Capitol Tasteland - What to Eat and See While in DC
description:
It's not quite the post-apocalypse yet, so join DC residents as they demystify the best way for a geek to hop the Potomac and grab a bite to eat and spend a little extra time in The District when the MAGFun is done.
Which single museum is worth cramming in before a Sunday flight, and how does one get to it? When you ask a mathematician where to eat, why does he say "AdMo"? Who did DC better: Bethesda or Ubisoft? What is a half-smoke? What is a Shadow Senator? Why were sandwiches from Taylor's Gourmet briefly worth $200? Where is the Murder Popeyes, and what, besides murder, is the real reason you should never eat there?
From National Harbor to National Landing to National Zoo: trivia, prizes, and your burning questions answered.

name: Fans and Game Developers
description: What exactly is the relationship between game makers and their fans? Is it merely the producer/consumer model or something more complex? In this panel we will explore the communication and interactions that emerge between creators and audiences in today's mediated world. What obligations to media producers have towards their audiences and how can they cultivate healthy customer relationships? From fan blaming and textual poaching to petitions and review bombing, this panel will attempt to sift the chaff from the fluff to ask the deeper question on how game developers and game players can play well together.

name: Magfest Challenges: Bringing excitement to Retro Games
description: Want to learn the magic behind the challenges that make your fingers numb? Learn the process of investigating, modifying, and redesigning retro games to make new challenges for everyone to....enjoy. Learn the restrictive creative freedom that working off someone else's finished product brings, help squash unexpected bugs, and gain skills you can use to upload your own challenge that will frustrate an entire convention next year. Also, with the audience's help we will make an all new challenge live, which you can brag about having a hand in making as it goes out to the challenge floor. Bring your best ideas or enjoy learning about the secrets that games hide behind the code, as we dissect old games live on stage!

name: Music and Influencer Collaborations are the Future, but what about Copyright Issues?
description:
There’s never been a better opportunity to build symbiotic relationships between musicians and content creators. Great content needs great music and great music needs to be heard. But what are some of the stumbling blocks content creators can run into? During this session, key industry members and content creators will take the team through what could happen if a creator uses an artist’s music without their permission, what some emergency technologies are that can help, and what the music industry thinks about UGC and ‘influencers’ - all while breaking down the role DMCA plays in this landscape. 

The panelists will also explore what the music industry is doing to counteract content creators from using their IP and what platforms are doing to supply music or safeguard you from using infringed material.

name: The Ins-&-Outs of Future Funk! with FIBRE and Discoholic
description:
Future funk star FIBRE & funk-minded (and ball-headed) Discoholic present: “The Ins-&-Outs of Future Funk”! What is it? Why is it so popular? How do you make it?

If you’ve ever pondered the above, look no further as FIBRE & Discoholic delve into sample searching, production, audio engineering, & more! FIBRE demystifies Future Funk’s sampling, production, & engineering, as Discoholic dissects the musical inner workings of the samples behind beloved Future Funk anthems (think MACROSS 82-99, TANUKI, Saint Pepsi).

FIBRE is a DJ & producer who’s no stranger to the craft of Future Funk. After exploding onto the scene thru hard-hitting releases via legendary Future Funk label Future Society Collective (w/ Yung Bae, Vantage, Moe Shop), him & Discoholic launched Montaime in 2017: a diverse palette of artists inspired by Disco, ft. digital & physical releases from Vantage, android52, The Phantom’s Revenge, & more.

Discoholic is a DJ, producer, & performer who isn’t afraid to have fun—fusing funky sensibilities, buttery-smooth transitions, & healthy doses of physical comedy—all while maintaining a dance-friendly groove that goes down smooth, like a bartender of discoholic beverages satisfying your tastes: Future Funk, R&B, Disco, you name it! The bar is open, would you like a drink?

name: Introduction to Vtubing!
description: Vtubing - the new trend that's taking over the internet! Getting started with streaming and streaming with a Vtuber seems daunting, but actually can be easy to set up and do with some basic equipment and imagination. At this panel we'll discuss the evolution of Vtubing, Vtube technology, the many paths to becoming a Vtuber, and do an animation demo in Live 2D showing how to set up a custom avatar. We can even chat about our favorite Vtubers too!

name: Samus Vs. Ridley: A Metroid Historia
description: Explore the history and development of the OG Nintendo heroine, Samus Aran, gaming's oldest woman lead character with regular starring roles since her inception! What has remained consistent about her character over the years? What has changed? What's the deal with that dragon? What has been revealed about her secret origins, enemies, and allies in the comics and manga? Where might she go next?

name: No Mercy, No Limits: 20 Years of N64 Wrestling Mods
description: Twenty years ago WWF No Mercy was unleashed on the N64.  Featuring a branching story, a huge roster and a creation suite that can't be beat, it is widely considered the best wrestling game of all time even two decades later.  The only thing better than the base game is what fans did with it.  The thing that really gave this game life was the dedicated fan base who did things the original developers never imagined.  Join us on a journey through the history of modding from manually typing pages of hex on an N64 controller to the current ease of emulation and show off some of the best mods.  Hundreds of wrestlers, new arenas and match types and even full visual overhauls will be featured.  Come see and play the magic of modding!

name: Homecoming Halftime Show: Emperor Norton's Stationary Marching Band, Magnificent Danger, Master Sword, The Audio Gremlins
description:
Homecoming Halftime Show:
Emperor Norton's Stationary Marching Band, Magnificent Danger, Master Sword, The Audio Gremlins

Emperor Norton's Stationary Marching Band:
Raunchy circus roots. Polished precision performances. A joyful cacophony of Balkan, Klezmer and funk, with a tasteful thrash of metal thrown in for good measure. No matter the occasion, Emperor Norton’s Stationary Marching Band has got the brass to get you up and dancing.
Some whisper in hushed tones that ENSMB is the ultimate herald of mirthful discord, while others have gone mad at the mere mention of the name. It’s music shrouded in mystery and wicked intrigue. But there’s one thing we know for sure:
Dance!
Party!
Vibes!
Better come see for yourself
Horns will wail. Shoulders will shimmy. Faces will melt.

Magnificent Danger:
Magnificent Danger is a collective of mobile brass & percussion dishing out weird and funky mashups of iconic tunes from video games, anime, TV shows, and more. The band's eclectic fusion of New Orleans street band energy, riot jazz, and hip-hop has created a bizarre but danceable party that's appreciated by musicians and nerds alike.

Master Sword:
The Legend of Zelda gets HEAVY with Master Sword - the original power metal band based around Zelda lore and all those famous melodies you love.

The Audio Gremlins:
THE AUDIO GREMLIMS 

‘The Audio Gremlins’ were born in Everett, MA amongst an industrial Hell of breweries and metal fabrication. For this dynamic trio, no genre is off limits. Franky Language and Treeman scratch samples on vinyl, with Flowttiglio producing beats on drum machine creating a live and unique experience.

name: Metroid Dread: That’s So Raven?
description:
Well, it’s been technically 19 years since a new 2D Metroid experience, so we’re not just bouncing off the walls in excitement, we’d be doing it literally if possible, I kingdom for the spider ball!

Come on by and see some people not only willing to gush all about this beyond memorable game, but perhaps even consider some of the larger themes behind Samus’ latest journey (physically and mentally) and spark some shines from our great quips and ready insight.

Or so we’re pretending…

So no one should “dread” attending this experience. Come embrace your helplessness with us!

PS: I heard that Raven Beak already saw the panel before we even thought it up, having nothing but exemplary things to say; it’s that good…

name: Hacking To The Gate: A SciAdv Panel
description: Delusions, Time Travel, Robots and more. The Science Adventure series has been capturing visual novel fans and anime fans for over 10 years. This panel helps connects it all together. p.s it's all Kurisu's fault.

Friday Morning Freeform Larps
description:
FreeForm Larps: Friday 10am-2pm Saturday 10am-2pm 
Damocles Thread Development presents a selection of FreeForm Larps. FreeForm gaming is a very different experience for people who have never tried it before. The games will push people to become emotionally attached to their characters and deal with situations realistically. Come by and try something new with our FreeForm Larps. The selection available will vary each morning but may include:


Hemophiliacademics: A tense freeform game about vampires applying to grad school.

Welcome Home, Willow!: A freeform arts-and-crafts improv LARP about dryads making a hope for a new tree.

Send n00ds: A raucous comedic freeform LARP about a cyberpunk noodle joint during the lunch rush.

Faceless Saints: A meditative scene-based LARP about finding answers to life's questions in a haunted house.

Pounded In The Butt By A Microgame: An absurdist speed-dating LARP inspired by the works of Chuck Tingle.

name: Creating Pantheons for Your Roleplay Game
Project One More Level: Saving the Flash Games
description:
In this panel, the dev team of Three Beat Games will introduce their first project: Project One More Level. Project OML is a grassroots, community-centered, not-for-profit effort to save a select list of influential, popular, or just plain fun Flash games in an interactive time capsule, where they can then be enjoyed indefinitely. We aim to not only save the games, but also locate the authors of the games themselves, and interview them- finding out information otherwise lost to time. Finally, we will create a dedicated museum piece for the Project, and send it somewhere where we can guarantee the public will be able to access it indefinitely- like the University of Michigan's Computer and Video Game Archive, who have already agreed to host the Project.

This panel will explore the 20+ year old community formed around Flash games, the evolution of them over time, their impact on pop culture and gaming as a whole, and, finally, how the end of Flash has affected the scene. It will talk about our Project as well as touch on similar projects, such as BlueMaxima's Flashpoint. Finally, and, most importantly, it will educate the public on the importance of culture preservation, so that we don't lose these games to time like we did early films.

name: Video Game Hacker University
description: Want to learn how to hack your favorite 8 and 16 bit video games? I'll teach you how to change the graphics, rewrite the dialogue, even directly alter the game's programming!

name: DialogBOX LIVE: How I Spent My Year and a Half Quarantine
description:
Man, so 2020, am I right? Remember when the worst thing in the world was COPPA, and people were hearing about this virus that may or may not make its way over here? 

But that was like, 5 years ago. America's back, baby! And LaughingboyLP is back with 3 very lovely guests yet again to talk about how we've been the last... however long. Join us as we talk about our time apart, the things we missed, and our hopes and dreams for the future.

A group of experienced video game lawyers will fill you in on some of the latest developments in video game law.  Open Q&A will follow, so bring your questions (about lawsuits or anything else).

The panel will explore post-modernism as a tool deployed by Kojima with respect to the game's narrative, design, art style, and music. We will cover and include spoilers for every game in the Metal Gear main canon (excl. MG Acid, MG: Ghost Babel, and MG Rising).

name: Parenting the Toxic Player
description: This panel explores the challenge of managing socially destructive, sometimes referred to as toxic, play in cooperative game environments. Topics will include identifying and understanding the motivations behind toxic game play, constructively redirecting confrontational players, and creating a positive social environment for cooperative play. We will discuss how the strategies for parenting toddlers can be adapted to toxic players in order to improve everyone's game experience including that of the toxic player.

name: Let There Be Light: The Birth of Photon and Laser Tag, and a Marketing Plan that Would Make the Spaceballs Proud
description: Over 30 years ago, George Carter III, inspired by Star Wars, invented the first commercial laser tag system. Learn about the game, its inventor, the struggles to keep it alive, and the fantastic and sometimes bizarre marketing plan that put the Photon logo on EVERYTHING. Also, learn about the Photon documentary, currently in production and scheduled for release in 2022.

A cosplay contest for attendees of all ages and skill levels!
Been working all year on a full suit of EVA foam armor?  Sewing every night for a week to create an amazing ballgown?  Bought a costume and did some really cool makeup with it?  Come show it off on our stage, show up in character and impress our judges and audience!

Contestants will walk the stage and have a few moments to really get into character.  Our judges will pick 16 entries (groups or solo) to move forward into our "Brackets" where the audience will help vote who is the MAGfest 2022 cosplay champion!
AND! There is also an optional craftmenship contest for anyone who made at least 50% of their costume!  

Signups are at the Cosplay Repair Table at panel, while space is available.

name: Triforce Quartet
description: The Triforce Quartet is a traditional string quartet that plays video game music. It began innocently as a short Zelda medley for an encore of a recital in early 2007, but the video of using traditional string quartet instruments to play video game music gained viral popularity later that summer. Thanks to this, cellist Chad Schwartz was able to combine his love for video games, along with years of classical training, to arrange a variety of video game themes that even non-gamers can enjoy. The four members of the Triforce Quartet take audience members on an unforgettable musical journey.

description: When the pandemic caused a shutdown of multiple events and conventions in 2020, multiple performers and show runners had to adapt by hosting shows on streaming platforms like Twitch and YouTube. With the future of live events looking much better, the organizers of multiple VGM virtual shows come together to reflect on the past couple years, what worked, how the community came together, and who kicked a lot of butt during this time.

description: “I knew from the moment they walked into the room, this wasn’t going to be an ordinary panel.” This hour-long lecture explores the conventions of film noir, including characters, plot, and style. How do you bring these elements into an interactive medium? For answers, we will delve into how noir is used in games such as Max Payne, L.A. Noire, Grim Fandango, The Wolf Among Us, and Snatcher. From the iconic look to dialog, pace, and mechanics, learn how to bring the classic film genre to life in your next video game project.

name: GR3YS0N
description:
#GamerNotAGangster #OtakuGang #GNAG
A unique artist to say the least, Brooklyn native now Bethlehem, PA resident GR3YS0N is blazing a trail in his own niche. Incorporating his passion for video games and anime he has developed a brand of music that goes over very well with a thus far untapped market. Uniting tech wiz's with the culture of Hip Hop he has etched his name into the conversation of the Quaker State's top acts. Performing for the past 8 years, GR3YS0N has shared the stage with notable MC's and peers the likes of Kadesh Flow, Mickey Factz, Mega Ran, Richie Branson to name a few. that influence certainly reveals itself in GR3YS0N's penchant for pushing the envelope lyrically and composing outside of the box.

With his Gamer Not A Gangster motto, GR3YS0N is certainly acquiring fans and supporters one bar and performance at a time Not one to fear societal standards, GR3YS0N is a poster child for self esteem and individuality. Stay tuned as he continues to mark his mark.

description:
Do you smell that funk? Thankfully, you won’t need a gasmask for this event, because we’re about to get down and dirty on the fundamentals of making great grooves!

We’ll demonstrate and discuss methods of working alone and together as a band to make everyone’s feet tap and heads bob. We’ll also show you what it means to get in the “pocket,” help you develop your sense of time across multiple styles of music, refine instrumentation roles for comping and soloing, and in the spirit of the MAGFest Jam Clinic, have fun jamming together!

If you want to get down like James Brown and Jamiroquai met ToeJam & Earl on a Sonic the Hedgehog act, come on in! This workshop is for all skill levels and instruments, and we hope it will help you elevate your musicianship skills in both traditional and video game music contexts.

name: Narrative Storytelling in Game Design
description: It’s one thing to tell a story on the page, but another thing entirely to design a narrative that a player has to navigate. How can traditional narrative storytelling tools inform game design, and where do the tools diverge? In this panel, we’ll discuss games with effective narrative storytelling for traditional and interactive fiction, and why these stories are so effective. We’ll also discuss practical tips for writers who are trying to tell their own stories through games.

description:
Adventurer. Wisecracker. Friend. He will live furever in our hearts.

Please join us as we celebrate the life of Bubsy T. Bobcat. Friends and family will be invited to share their memories of this beloved video game superstar.

"In the end, it’s not the years in your life that count. It’s the life in your years."

—Abraham Lincoln

name: From Hotdogs to Smash Bros: Unique Jobs in Gaming
description:
For the past 10 years, I've worked in promotional marketing for various video game brands. From roadshows, to PAX, to the Super Smash Bros Ultimate release in Tyson’s Corner. What kind of background got me into this line of work? Simple... I started out selling hotdogs. 

Crazy right! You would be amazed by how many skills could snag you a job in the gaming industry, no coding or design necessary!

In this panel-workshop, we will discuss some of the unconventional careers in video games and the tools you will need to get your foot in the door.

name: Inverse Phase
description:
What happens when you're so obsessed with chiptunes and oldskool game music that you go to an event called MAGFest, then you have such a great time that you buy it and run it for ten years, and while you're doing that, you become so inspired by all the people you book as guests that you become a game musician yourself? Something like this, perhaps! 


Inverse Phase, evangelist of the demoscene and lover of pizza, once known as Mr. MAGFest, but you can call him Brendan, performs fun original game jams and tributes, all written on consoles and computers from before 1990. And he promises he won't try to talk too much on stage.

We will teach the basics of traditional Japanese-style Kusari weaving, a type of armor both similar to and notably different from western Chainmail. We'll teach you the basic So Kusari and Hana Kusari weaves, and send you home with a small piece forged by your own hands!
*This class cost $15 for supplies. Must have cash on hand at time of panel*

name: "Strange New Worlds:" Othering in Videogame Music
description: Imbuing a videogame's aesthetics with a sense of foreignness is a task which frequently falls on the composers and music designers. This panel will examine a series of tropes in game music and audio design to isolate and analyze commonalities, as well as discuss notable outliers. This panel will cover, but not spoil, soundtracks and games from the following series: Halo, NieR, Horizon, Control, Fallout/Wasteland, and more.

name: Jamspace Presents: The Friday Night Cyber Jam!
description:
Oh you thought you'd get away with just seeing the acts on main stage? GET READY TO HAVE YOUR MIND BLOWN TO THE BACK OF JAMSPACE! We've got the progressive prowess of Steel Samurai to start us off, followed by the RIP N' TEAR RAW ENERGY of those incredible synthwave powermetaling MEGATRONIX boys! To close out the evening in style we've got Jamspace newcomer, but absolute synthwave and DJ'ing Veteran Virtuoso, Faith in the Glitch! 

Consider your slam: CYBER JAMMED.

name: Rambling On My Mind: A Survey of the Blues

name: Games At Work: A serious games primer
description: For many years, games have been used as teaching tools, from rote repetition to complex simulations. Based on ideas from the book Serious Games, this discussion looks into the different patterns used by games to try and teach their players, what works, what doesn't, and what the future of serious games looks like.

name: Negativland + SUE-C
description:
Negativland + SUE-C
"We Can Really Feel Like We’re Here"
A live cinema + music + sound collage performance piece for MAGFest
 
 Does technology help connect people?  Or does it replace them?  As the tools of one age become the masters of the next, it’s precisely the gaming community that knows the Metaverse existed long before its recent corporate rebranding.  In "We Can Really Feel Like We’re Here," live cinema artist SUE-C and metamedia group Negativland collage the last century’s worth of technology — the one now being resold back to us as our future.  But from Sensorama to Oculus, from Second Life to PlayStation Home, from I Love Bees to Twitter — there’s only so much gamification that the real world is ever going to allow.

NEGATIVLAND
Since 1980, the multimedia collective known as Negativland have been creating records, CDs, video, fine art, books, radio and live performance using appropriated sounds, images, objects, and text. Mixing original materials and original music with things taken from corporately owned mass culture and the world around them, Negativland re-arrange these found bits and pieces to make them say and suggest things that they never intended to. In doing this kind of cultural archaeology and "culture jamming" (a term they coined way back in 1984), Negativland have been sued twice for copyright infringement. Their art and media interventions pose both serious and silly questions about the nature of sound, media, technology, control, ownership, propaganda, power, and perception in the United States of America. Their work is now referenced and taught in many college courses in the US, has been written about and cited in over 150 books and legal journals, and their favorite video game is Katamari Damacy.

SUE-C
SUE-C is a projectionist, engineer and educator working at the intersection of creative coding and live performance. She has created handmade videos and live media performances, taught college level courses and workshops, and traveled extensively in the USA and internationally since 1999. Her work blends technology, photography, video and everyday objects into an improvisational animation “instrument” using her own custom software and live cameras. Working in tandem with musicians, “her camera is equipped like a microscope, turning the scrap store objects into a visual equivalent of ASMR.” (From The Wire, November 2021). When not performing, teaching, parenting or making NFTs she is usually trying to finish a stack of books while petting one of five cats.

name: SUPER ART FIGHT
description: The Greatest Live Art Competition in the Known Universe RETURNS to MAGFest! Cheer your favorite artists onto victory, but watch out for the amazing topics of the crowd sourced WHEEL OF DEATH! You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll have an unforgettable time!

name: Accountability and Toxicity in VGM Orchestras
description: From the Washington Metropolitan Gamer Symphony Orchestra,  Amanda, Soumya and Jasmine will address further Accountability and Toxicity in regards to keeping VGM Orchestras running. These are topics we touch on in "So I started a VGM Orchestra, now how do I keep it running?" We explore how to make sure to keep your organization accountable and how to reverse toxicity that may have taken root. This will include discussions on how to keep everyone on the same page for tasks, how to handle spicy interactions, formation of grievance committees and how to spot and reverse toxicity in a VGM Orchestra.

*This class cost $15 for supplies. Must have cash on hand at time of panel*

name: Challenger Approaching - Perfecting a Fighting Game OST
description:
Since the days of Street Fighter II and even through Super Smash Bros. Ultimate, fighting game music has complimented the game’s pacing and kept players hooked for many years. This panel will explore the impact of songs from fighting games that have stood the test of time across several titles and generations, for everyone from button mashing casuals to music theory enthusiasts and arcade veterans.

Even outside of the game, many casual players still consider these tunes as “certified bangers”, and have introduced some players to the fighting game genre. This panel will delve into how a fighting game OST can compliment its game along with how it relates to greater world musical culture in order to leave an impact both in the game and on the listener. Featuring interviews with musicians, musical analysis, ludiological connections, and why several boppin’ tunes slap as hard as they do, come along as we “take you for a ride” into the “soy sauce” for fighting games.

name: A New Challenger Approaches!
description:
If you’re done being bombarded by AAA titles, tired of sequel-itis, and looking to take a break from staring at your phone well do we have a panel for you! DC Gaming Group is calling on you to throw down and compete for glory and MAGfest cred! There won’t be any Guilty Gear: Strive or Super Smash Bros Ultimate going on here. Instead, contestants will be pit against each other in unsung titles of video game history. Exactly what games will you all be playing? Well that’s a surprise! 

DC Gaming Group (DCGG) is an organization created to foster gaming connections. Together, we can explore new games, support independent game developers, and check out local events. DCGG welcomes gamers of all walks of life to come together and play—console players, PC gamers, tabletop enthusiasts, mobile players—we don’t judge! Our goal is to bring folks with different gaming preferences together in the same community. If you are just getting into gaming or want to learn about new games, you have a place at DCGG.

name: What Kind of Yakuza are You Anyway?: Honor and Integrity in Grand Theft Auto III
description:
In honor of this landmark games' 20th birthday in October 2021, let's take a look into what drives Claude, the main character, and how his actions and decisions point to something darker than we might first notice. 
What can Claude tell us about his world? More importantly, what can Claude tell us about ourselves?

description:
DJ Block - GrooveCube, VGR, tetracase, DV-i

GrooveCube:
A Groovy Cube trying to fit into a circular world.

VGR:
Blending his talent and passion for electronic music with a strong sense of gamer nostalgia, VGR reimagines iconic themes and songs from his favorite anime and games as main-stage, EDM festival-style bangers. Having previously partnered with Cartoon Network for projects such as the official Steven Universe Future Remix compilation, VGR has released tracks on prestigious labels including Monstercat and produced music for video games such as the award-winning, cross-platform Rocket League under his original music alias Nokae.
 With more than 240,000 subscribers on YouTube, 800,000 monthly listeners on Spotify, and 200 million plays across all platforms, VGR has made it his mission to take anime and game music to the next level.

tetracase:
Meet Tetracase, east-coast based friends making a name for themselves around the world by infusing Drum and Bass with a nostalgic video game sound. The group has also branched out to make Future Funk, Breaks, Jersey Club, and anything else fast and fun. They gained a greater following after their remix of Anamanaguchi’s "Triangle", which led to releases on Liqucity, Tiny Waves and Game Chops.

DV-i:
DV-i is a VGM musician from NYC

description:
PLACE YOUR BETS!
Come one, come all to the greatest fighting event of the season! Watch as two computer controlled fighters duke it out for your entertainment! Bet your worth in salt and pray you don’t get sent to the salt mines.
Salty Bet Live! will be a crowd participation game where you choose which computer-controlled, randomly selected MUGEN character will win a match.
Rules are simple: We’ll be streaming Salty Bet on a big screen. Before a match starts, you will stand on the side of the room that the character you best think will win the match. You’ll cheer on your fighter and get as rowdy as you can. If your character wins, you get to stay in. If your character loses, you go to the salt mines.
There will be prizes and we promise they will be stupid.

name: True Stories of the MAGFest Staff
description:
True Stories of the MAGFest Staff -

MAGFest is a massive organization with a particular quirk: It's almost entirely run by volunteers. Ever wonder what it takes to make this event happen every year? Join our panel of long-time MAGFest staffers from all walks, as we share some wild stories, humorous anecdotes, and teach you about what it means to eat, sleep, and breath MAGFest all year round!

During the dance you’ll be able to hang with your friends, pick arguments with your frenemies, and moon over your crush, just like any other high school dance. But when your music is playing, you’re empowered by it and become the most powerful being on the dance floor—and maybe the entire gymnasium! At the end of the night, one of you will be elected Dance Monarch and enact a powerful ritual that can permanently change the world. Game will run from 12:30 -3.

name: YouTube Poop: An Involuntary Art Movement
description: It started out as a joke. It was never meant to be taken seriously. Now, YouTube Poop (the art of editing videos into nonsense to make people laugh for reasons that psychology doesn't fully understand) has become a legitimate art movement, mentionable in the same breath as 19th century French Impressionism. How could this happen? The answers lie deeper than you might think. Grab a leg in one hand and a BRERB in the other, it's time to dive in.

name: Creating an Experience: Marketing Tips & Tricks for Your Indie Game
description: Did you know, that, on average, ten games are released on Steam every day? This begs the question "Is my game (insert adjective) enough to stand out?" The first step to successfully launching and marketing a title is to develop one strong enough to entice the right audience. The next step is to market the heck out of it! Using stories from our own experiences, this panel will delve into tips and tricks behind building a successful plan for your game's release, from community building to marketing copy. You've developed a game, now it's time to get people to play it!

name: Loading Snacks Presents: Being Comfortable Being a Geek
description: Are you comfortable being a geek? How can we help each other be more comfortable being who we are? This panel will open the discussion on the definition of “Geek” and how it has changed in recent years. We will discuss how our level of comfort with this and other labels has changed as more of obscure pastimes such as reading comic books/manga, playing video games and watching anime has bled over into the mainstream. This is a discussion. Let us share our stories and empower each other to be comfortable as we are! Moderated by Gage of Loading Snacks!

name: Becoming a "Trans Synth Queen":  YouTube, Electronic Music Composition, and Coming Out
description:
Educators can develop musical learning experiences that help trans students explore, develop, and celebrate their genders and identities through music. I explored how a trans musician might develop an identity that aligned with the gender they wanted to present, construct a digital self that affirms their gender identity, and interacted parasocially—mediated exchanges that are at least as meaningful as offline relationships—with other YouTube users and VGM musicians on the platform. This case study (modeled from Stake, 1995) explored how a well-established YouTube Video Game Music musician, Amie Waters, used social media platforms and her music to express herself as she came out as trans to her audiences online. Amie’s experiences and practices can inform how we in music education might encourage trans students to pursue music—both online and offline—that expresses their gender and other aspects of their identities in positive and meaningful ways.


Amie found trans resources and role models on online platforms, which helped her develop her identity as a non-binary person. She used Twitter, her personal blog, and YouTube to present her self-image while interacting parasocially with others who provided her emotional, creative, and financial support. Amie’s YouTube channel included coming out in which she explained who she was, her gender, and how her music helped her understand herself and process emotions. Furthermore, she released two albums of electronic music one inspired by her sexuality and the other by her gender. Her musical releases on YouTube helped Amie construct, perform, and express her identity. Amie’s DIY music and recording processes bore a video archive of comings out that show how music can be used understand gender, trans identity, and sexuality, as well as how music empowered Amie through composition and the creation of recordings. Amie's original music and video game music covers helped her work through emotions and provide acceptance and understanding of her own life.

name: Trying to Retro in a 4K World: Art & Science of Replaying the Past
description: Enjoying classic video games has never been easier, thanks to the prevalence of re-releases and advances in emulation plus technology as a whole, but are they truly the games of old? Can we reproduce those cherished experiences, and even if so, shouldn’t improvements be made along the way? What’s more important: accuracy or just a fun game? Topics include: what's been preserved, what's been improved upon, and what's been left in the past, for better or worse. We'll be covering efforts to port, re-imagine, restore, and archive games, from early software emulation (NESticle) to MAME (Multiple Arcade Machine Emulator) to FPGA's (Field Programmable Raid Arrays). Also discussed is what can't be easily preserved and replicated: defunct online servers, delisted mobile games, expired-license sports, characteristics of controllers, and music games.

description: Let’s face it: 2021 was an incredible year for video games, and now that 2022 has arrived, it’s time to honor the best of the best… and we need your help to do it! In this highly-structured (yet comically-inclined) debate panel, willing participants from the audience will make their GOTY arguments, field questions from a panel of 2021 game experts, and face the stats of real-time audience polling. What game will reign supreme? The true jury of 2021 - the attendees of MAGFest - will decide.

name: MAGFest in VR: The Making of the VRChat “MAGLord”
description:
What do you do when a pandemic keeps everyone from going to MAGFest in person? Naturally you make your own virtual MAGFest in VR for all to enjoy! Come learn about the "MAGLord," a series of virtual reality worlds custom-made to capture the MAGic of MAGFest, and to give virtual attendees a place to meet up, hang out, and stream content. (Looking for a virtual recreation of the concert hall to relive a past year's concert? We gotchu.) Best of all, the MAGLord is free to all, either on VR or desktop (PC), on the free VRChat platform.

Our panel of project developers will talk about the goals, themes, and features of these virtual spaces; the tools and technologies that power them; the community and events these spaces have served over the pandemic year; and the development efforts of the group of MAG staff and fans that have put it all together. We'll also showcase some of the best that VRChat has to offer, with a showcase of our favorite partner projects and VR worlds! 

Q&A to follow, and catch us after to talk more about the ongoing project!

Have a conversation with museum professionals as they provide a crash-course in caring for collections and answer questions!

name: Yoga for Gamers - Reset Your System - Saturday
description: Connect the wires within your human system and recharge through mindful movement and relaxation techniques, backed by video game music soundtracks. Yoga and gaming have more in common than you'd think - we will explore relevant concepts shared by both "practices" and reframe how we navigate reality-- on and off the screen. Each of the classes will have a mixture of concepts and practices that may be relaxing, physical, contemplative, or focused. All-levels class, and no previous experience necessary. Remember: to be your best, you'll need focus, and to keep a full health bar; there are no 1-ups in real life!

name: Why Do Early Pokémon Designs Still Work So Well?
description: Despite there being nearly 1,000 Pokémon from over twenty-five years' worth of games to choose from, many people's favorites still come from the first generation. Made up of only 150 monsters, these creatures have designs that are instantly recognizable and often iconic. This panel will discuss why they're so effective and how they only enhance the themes of the franchise itself.

name: Moms vs Machines (and Dads too)
description: As parents, we guide our kids through the game of life every day. Let's talk about how gaming and technology helps our families thrive, and how it doesn't. Moderator Sue Slagle is a creative technology artist and parent of two kids who love gaming. She has been thinking about the impacts of technology on the family since around 2010, and sometimes blogs about it. Bring your ideas, your experiences, your frustrations and your desire to connect with other parents and let's talk. This workshop will start with a short presentation and then be open for discussion.

Do yo have questions about how locksmiths help you get into your house or car when you left your keys? Stop by the Lockpicking Village for your chance! Locks and tools will be available. Capacity will be limited. Once the room is at capacity, attendees will be allowed in on a "one in-one out" basis throughout the time that the village is open.

name: "Burdened with Glorious Purpose:” 21st-Century Zeitgeist and the Shifting Perspectives in Portrayal of Marvel and DC Superheroes on the Big Screen
description: The 20th Century witnessed the rise of two of the largest, most recognizable publishers in the comics industry: Marvel and Detective Comics. These giants evolved with the ongoing social, political, and economic trends and reflected many of the issues surrounding the 20th Century. The beginning of the 21st Century, however, marked a sharp turn in worldwide relations and politics. This panel will examine the shifting perspectives on the preceding century's tropes in print Marvel and DC comics and their cinematic adaptations, and will include a discussion of the directorial, narrative, and musical choices in these adaptations. Panel will contain spoilers for films from the Marvel Cinematic Universe, DC Expanded Universe, and the Christopher Nolan "Dark Knight" trilogy.

name: Learning Reaper: The Best Digital Audio Workstation No One Knows About
description: Reaper is one of the most flexible and complete DAWs on the market today. Created by the maker of WinAmp, it is supported by a loyal fan base that is continually adding functionality. As a result, it is being adopted by many freelance engineers, studios, and game companies as their DAW of choice. In this lecture, we will be exploring this DAW. We will walk through the quirks and demystify its operation by deconstructing a full mix.

name: Let your Ears Do the Work: Music Production and Mixing with Richie Beretta
description: In this panel, producer and mixer Richie Beretta, who has worked with artists like Beyonce, Diplo, Major Lazer, Guy Fieri (ok not Daddy Fieri but soon I promise), will walk through and explain the methods used in song that he worked on that is now currently released (song TBD).  He'll break down each track and explain the methods used to create a track to be as competitive as possible in today's music market place.  Topics discussed will not only be the tangible techniques like EQ, Compression, Arrangement etc., but also how to embrace a more philosophical approach to creating a successful and emotionally compelling song.  We already own the strongest tool when it comes to making music - our ears.

name: One Hit Wonders! Bandoake
description: Imagine singing karaoke with a live band... Now imagine that the songs are selected at random by a large spinning wheel. The band has 5 minutes to learn the song before launching into epic and often hilarious renditions of your favorite pop tunes. Audience participation is highly suggested for singers and instrumentalists of all stripes. Now in its fourth year of production, Jam Clinic Bandaoke presents: ONE HIT WONDERS!

name: Dead by Daylight Tournament
description: Yes, we have lost our minds. We are running a DbD tournament, the competitive game that has no clear victory condition! So build yourself a team of 4 and let the Entity take over!

name: From Game Industry to Hollywood to VTuber. Capt Crabs Q and A
description: Capt Crabs has worked over 18 years in the Gaming Industry for companies like BioWare and Bethesda.  He also has done post work on Hollywood films and tv such as NCIS, Black Sails, Stargirl and more. He does DJing and VTubing as well. Come ask questions about anything!

name: Cybercrime 2077: An Ongoing Autopsy Of “Pandemic-Era” Video Game Hacking
description:
In the last two years, we have seen some of the craziest hacks and most damaging leaks in the world of video games - everything from hacking players through name changes in Fall Guys, the Nintendo “GigaLeaks” which confirmed that “L Is Real”, and the fact that games such as Cyberpunk 2077 and Sonic Colors Ultimate were apparently made out of the digital equivalent of popsicle sticks and chewing gum.

Join the hackers from DCG 201 as they dissect this endless dumpster fire of leaks, breaches, privacy fails, scams, homebrew and software hacks from the beginning of 2020 to the present in order to find out if there is any light at the end of the tunnel while having laughs along the way! There will be time at the end of this presentation for the MAGFest audience to ask questions to our hacker panelists.

name: Women in Games, Games for Girls, and Video Gaming’s Messy History
description: In 1995, Entertainment Weekly's CD-ROM of the year was a folk-art fueled game about a little girl and her best friend. The next year, Barbie Fashion Designer was a breakout hit. Dozens of companies rushed to make and market games for girls. But, within a few years, most titles had gone out of print and multiple companies had folded. What went wrong? And, what can we learn from this episode of the recent past?

description: Since 2013, Sean Monistat has been producing sci-fi and horror film-influenced chiptune materiel as +LET'S DISINFECT!+. Applying the DIY ethos of punk rock to an electronic setting, it is his mission to focus the gist of a lifetime spent in dark subculture into crushingly cathartic music.

name: Scales in the Sky: Falcom Music from Ys to Trails & More
description: Join a veteran of the Ys and Trails RPG fandom once again as they discuss the wonders of developer Nihon Falcom’s game music! This year’s panel will both introduce Falcom’s musical legacy--and why it matters--as well as entertain long-time fans. We’ll talk about their history, musicians, usage of leitmotif and, of course, their albums. We’re covering a variety of genres and songs, ranging from early years to modern tunes, revealing their house style and critical details hiding in plain sight. Stick around to hear great Falcom songs, get your questions answered, and celebrate the company’s achievements in game music and beyond!

name: Disco Elysium Larp - Revachol with Love (or at least something your Lizard brain could mistake for it) Larp
description: Part urban myth and part political science, rumblings echo through the trash and graffiti-ridden streets of Revachol that Le Retour (the return) is coming. Communist thinkers, free verse poets, and streetside prophets (read: the inebriated) agree that something rumbles in the very soul of the city, that a return to self-governance or its total destruction lies in the near future. The tension between the locals, big business, the state, and the malcontents could be cut by a knife (and might go well with a side of jam.)  After a major business is burned down, the district is placed on lockdown by the Coalition all the elements are contained like a keg just waiting to blow. Disco Elysium Larp is a surreal Theatre Larp for people 16+. No knowledge of the game is required to play. Character creation starts at 7:30. Game start at 8:15 and will run till around

name: Game Fast, Die Young
description: The video game industry is an unforgiving wasteland, so making it as a dev takes a lot of skill and very little shame. Over the course of an hour, we will develop a game, in entirety, from pre-production to launch. Let's get this game done, quick.

name: Black Joy within Gaming Culture
description: At the same time, Black Joy is can a state of being that does not have to be in contention with something to exist. "Black Joy" is a effective form of expression of bringing forward positive actions within and through resistance to white hegemony and racism.  African-Americans in gaming culture share a history through which one can analyze black expressive culture. Javon Goard will present an introduction to the history and contemporary involvement of African Americans within the game industry and discuss how this ties into the concept of Black Joy.

name: Shubzilla x Bill Beats
description: Shubzilla and Bill Beats began working together in 2011. Starting with the single "Wonderful World" for "Bill Beats For President Vol.1," the duo moved on to make more albums, including “The Kong Quest,” the single “GOLDEN,” and most recently “The Belmont Tapes.” They have SXSW, MAGfest 2018, The Never Give Up Never Surrender Tour under their belts, along with performances at Norwescon, the PAXWest Nerdcore Showcase, and many others. Shubzilla and Bill Beats are the founders and hosts of Noir Grime’s Friday Night Get Down, a monthly hip hop showcase in the Seattle area. With Shubzilla's frank and aggressive lyrics and Bill Beats' penchant for samples and bass-heavy compositions, they do not disappoint.

They're back better than ever, and ready to rock your world! Expect soaring vocals, an abundance of twin guitar pyrotechnics, and melodies so infectious you'll need a lobotomy.

name: The Fundamentals of Audio: Building a Foundation of First Principles
description: The first principles of any field of study are an essential component in learning more complex concepts.  Mastering these concepts will allow you to solve problems, dissect techniques, and create new methods of your own.  In this lecture, Dr. Cresci will present the first principles of audio production, The recording chain, and the eight basic characteristics of sound.

name: Mega Ran
description:
After having a record debut at number 6 on Billboard’s Top New Artist Chart most rappers would probably celebrate by hitting the nightclub. Mega Ran celebrated by visiting his local Boys & Girls Club in Phoenix to speak to teens about technology in an ever-changing world.
After leaving his teacher’s desk for the final time over a decade ago, Mega Ran (Raheem Jarbo) has repurposed his teaching voice to become one of the premier voices for positive hip-hop. With his latest release, “Live ‘95” the renowned wordsmith is exploring the cross-section between urban life, hip-hop, and basketball, an intersection that was so crucial to not only his upbringing but his overall success in the music industry.

name: World Building Through Improv Workshop
description: This workshop focuses on translating skills from improvisational acting to group roleplaying in TTRPGs and the kind of worldbuilding that goes into the design of place and space in games across media. The workshop will demonstrate how spatial scene work and dialog can "build" spaces in the mind's eye; how we can variously insinuate visual details outside of direct description; and will explore how to develop transitions between spaces by using the full dimensions of the stage and movement. This is a participatory workshop where attendees will act out various scenarios and discuss ideas for porting these skills to the games they play.

name: CLAW MACHINES TOURNAMENT
description: There are two independent sessions for the CLAW MACHINES tournament, please plan to attend only one.

name: End of Fest Dance Party
description: Another Magfest has come and gone, but this one doesn't end until this dance party turns out the lights! Come and celebrate the weekend in the Arena and dance the night away!

name: Mom! The Gacha stole my credit card again!
description:
What are Gacha? How much does one need to spend to truly become a whale? What exactly is pity? 

Join us as we discuss the term "gacha" and what qualifies a game to fit under the umbrella term. We will be looking at popular games with a gacha system such as FGO, Genshin, and Arknights, and what psychological aspects these games have to keep you constantly willing to open your wallet. Your wallet should be safe from this panel, but no promises.

name: Goblins!
description: You want to know about goblins? Why you asking? Who are you? Fine. We just so happen to be goblin hysterical-ians. We know all the hysterical stories of the goblins. I'm Cyl Maddhatta, da best goblin. There's also Faygo, da Fetcha and Holda of Things and Veg, my favorite grot. We're going to tell you everything you need to know about goblins and where to find them.

name: The Megas w/visuals by Claire Kwong
description:
The Megas are a general group of dudes from Los 
Angeles, heading to MAGFest to deliver their synth rock anthems inspired by the Mega Man and Castlevania series.

name: Whose Roll is it Anyway?
description: The greatest Role-Playing Game in the known multiverse! Join our players and the Dungeon Master as they seek gold and glory in a world created entirely by YOU! The monsters, the spells, the loot, and even the NPC dialogue are all created by the audience! What could possibly go wrong? Come watch this table of professional idiots desperately try to weave your ideas into a semi-coherent narrative. Heroes will rise. Dice will roll. The Gygax estate will inevitably sue.

name: Chrono Trigger - Jets of Time Randomizer (Any%) with SaintVonJester

name: Why are you here? We aren't. Chip Rave is happening!
description: I deliberately added this just to be a cheeky nerd. Seriously though, go check out all the awesome acts from a bunch of the chipmusic communities at chip rave this year!

name: Chiprave - Star Fighter Dreams  w/visuals by dr!p, nullsleep  w/visuals by Pixelseed, defense mechanism  w/visuals by emdash, Cass Cuttlefish  w/visuals by Claire Kwong, DINAARI  w/visuals by silent antagonist
description:
NULLSLEEP is an electronic musician based in Tucson, AZ who produces high-concept / low-tech rave anthems for the end of the world. Employing outdated soundchips alongside bleeding edge hardware, he has spent the past 20 years reimagining a technological history of electronic music and mutating the genre-defining sounds in his own productions. PLUR in the face of mass extinction.

Cass Cuttlefish:
Dreamy, Dancey, Digital. Cass Cuttlefish is the sleepy cephalopod girl who not only makes chill chiptune beats, but who also runs the collective A Bit of Chiptune.

DINAARI is the newest project from the creator of Dachampster and Sasha Ruins Everything. Channeling various energies into Famitracker, the content of DINAARI's releases and shows can never be predicted.

Star Fighter Dreams is a San Antonio-based electronic musician. Using a variety of handhelds and software such as LSDJ, Piggy Tracker and Nanoloop, he crafts track after track of energetic tunes in different styles

DEFENSE MECHANISM is a chiptune musician who combines intricate compositional prowess with a love of catchy melodies
to create kickass dance tunes using LSDj on a Nintendo Gameboy.

name: Can We Beat Beethoven on the Super Nintendo?
description:
The panel that was supposed to be here got canceled, which means there's only one thing to do: stay up late and see if we can collectively conquer the greatest game about a St. Bernard ever made. 
Very serious video game historians Frank Cifaldi and Kelsey Lewin from the Video Game History Foundation will lead this audience participation effort to see this game through to its end. If we succeed, there's a prize! If we fail, there is only shame.

name: MIDNIGHT MOVIE: The Cabinet of Dr Caligari, with Live Improvised Soundtrack by Emperor Norton's Stationary Marching Band and Friends
description: Join ENSMB and other musical guests of MAGfest as they improvise a live score to the expressionistic horror masterpiece THE CABINET OF DOCTOR CALIGARI.

name: 1993 Downloading Spree
description: What was it like to get online before the Internet was a "thing"? With just an old DOS machine and a phone line, Inverse Phase will show us what it was like to get online for free and download music, games, and more.... in 1993.

name: Geek Jeopardy!
description:
Jeopardy, but with geeky topics and questions!

Insofar as I can remember all the rules, that is…

Having been a fan of gameshows at conventions for more than a decade, it was troubling how contingent audience enjoyment could be based on the ability of the contestants that the hosts choose. 

As arranging for certain choices ahead of time seemed ineffective to me (celebrity gameshows), I followed the lead of veteran panelists (Thrown Controllers, Name that Tune) in only requiring potentials to pass a quick test to earn a spot in the game. Feedback has always been positive to this innovation.

To this end, this was also an opportunity to get the rest of the audience involved as well, which is facilitated by the multiple choice nature of the questions (if necessary), and the ability of the audience to feel like active participants when able. 

Fans of the Jeopardy format can expect a much more well-rounded event that makes the event less based on the luck of the draw and potentially too obscure knowledge that can hold back contestant and audience fun alike.

name: Ritual of the New Year: Mage the Ascension Larp
description:
Come join us Sister and Bother Mages. We, the Verbena invite you to the Yearly Gathering. We must once again Perform the ritual of the New Year.

All will workers welcome and needed. The old year must once again be bound so the New Year is prosperous. Please we need your HELP!

Will trade powerful magical secrets to all that are willing to aid us.

name: Live Reading of the MAGFest Dating Simulator 2021
description: "MAGFest 2021 Dating Simulator Ultra Redux: Chain of Memories The Video Game" was the ultimate 2021 digital handholding experience of 2021. Now join us at the real MAGFest where we will we play the game live together! We'll explore the halls of the Gaylord, meet up with characters like Shrek, the cult of Imhotep, and others, all while trying to find some top tier cutie pie to hold our hands so we can rock out to the Protomen! The audience will decide which path we follow on our way to finding our true love! Will they unlock the good ending, or will they get the the end of MAG with their hand unheld? Lets find out together!

name: Craziest Japanese Commercials
description: What does a cheese based alien, a ramen car chase and Tommy Lee Jones have in common? They are all part of the weirdest and funniest commercials from Japan! Come see some!

name: Closing time :( No more museum this year :(
description: Museum is closed

name: YouTube Poop and Internet Remix Culture
description:
YouTube Poop panels are BACK! This time we have a group of YTP veterans including the CREATOR of YouTube Poop to tell you about the history of our community and the artform everyone on the internet has learned to love or hate.

We plan to return to the convention scene with a bang, so come see some insight on historical poops, and maybe dinner blaster will make a return? Gotta be there to find out!

name: Super Mario 64 (120 Star / 120 Runner) Super magFAST Super Finale!
description: Speedrun of Super Mario 64 with 120 people each getting a single star from the game and then passing the controller. Check out https://horaro.org/magfast/2022 for the most accurate schedule.

name: Performer and Guest Merchandise for sale!
description: Hours of Operation for Rock Island - where the wonderful merchandise for our performers & guests is sold! Come check us out!

name: MAG N Seek swap meetups
description: MAG N Seek swap meetups are the swag swap panels to accompany the Swag N Seem treasure hunt going on all weekend.

name: Advanced Pokemon GO for the casual or returning player
description:
Last year PoGo celebrated their fifth anniversary (as best they could as a social game in a pandemic). This brought many new players in while convincing many more to return. Others found that because of the pandemic they no longer had the ability or drive to continue playing and are just now returning.

This panel aims to bring together information integral to success in the game. We will cover efficient tactics for leveling, earning coins, coin use, gathering stardust, and finding the best 'mons. There will be some discussion of PVP, without treading into the deep end of high-tier competitive play.

name: Arcade Repair: How to be your own Fix-it Felix
description: Ever wonder how MAG keeps 300 plus arcade machines running for 4 days straight?  We don't. They break and here's how we repair them.  Veteran arcade and pinball technicians who maintain the machines for MAGFest will show you some basic repairs and tips on how to maintain your own home collection.

name: Quiet Room Open Hours
description: Need a break from all of the noise and the excitement? Come to the Quiet Room to decompress for a while!

name: Starship Horizons
description: Starship Horizons is a team based multi-player experience that is designed to be played together. The players command their own Starship as the bridge officers in the roles of Captain, Flight, Tactical, Science, Operations, and Engineering.

name: 7 Wonders Organized Play
description: Do you like 7 Wonders? Do you like Mpoints?  Then come on down to play! Games will start at the top of each hour, stay for as many or as few games as you like!

name: Weapons to Surpass Metal Gear
description: The Metal Gear series is (in)famous for some of its ridiculous weapons and equipment, but truth can be stranger than fiction. From the pigeon guided missile, to the time that the CIA planned to nuke the moon, history is full of stupid solutions to real problems. And some, despite common sense, actually worked.

name: MAGFest Charity Auction
description: This will be out 12th charity auction for a childs Play charity.

name: Great Lighting and Passion: The keys to making it as a Game Developer
description: Join Conner as he explains why lighting can make or break a video game, and how passion is the key to being successful in game design.

name: How Music Rhythm Games and VR Have Changed How We Experience and Discover Music
description: Since the advent of games such as "Just Shapes and Beats", "Beat Saber", and "Synth Riders", we have stumbled on new ways to consume music. But, these games have changed so much more than just how we listen to music, they have changed how we experience, connect and discover music. Learn more about how video games have changed the landscape of music forever.

name: So You Wanna Be a Game Master...
Smash Bros. Melee
description: Sign-up at the Ops desk in Consoles.

name: Smash Bros. Ultimate
description: Sign-up at the Ops desk in Consoles.

name: Sit Down, STFU, & Play This J-RPG (Deluxe Edition)
description: Whether it be tactical, date simmy, grinding, training your mons, a hybrid of all of those, or ??? (profits?), you need to play these RPGs, exactly right now.  Come to this panel to get some awesome game recommendations & listen to the panelist wax poetic about all the nostalgia feelz for some amazing JRPGs she’s played in her lifetime.

name: What We Can Learn from Trash:  Terrible Films and You
description:
Good lessons can be learned from the good.  GREAT lessons can be learned from the terrible.  Bad cinema is one of the greatest assets any creative mind can ask for:  Learning what NOT to do and and what just DOES NOT work.  For 60 minutes, witness Emmy-winning Video Producer Eddie Lebron demonstrated and educate through horrible cinema how you can improve your craft as an artist, creative, and overall person just from the trash you've been watching.  It will be fun, educational, and life changing*
*Life changes not guaranteed.

name: AI and Video Games: A Two-Way Street
description: Every video game designer and player has played against or created an AI and knows that AI quality can make or (more often) break a game.  AI research has contributed a lot to video games, but now the tables have turned and researchers are using video games not as an application for AI, but as a research tool.  This panel will talk about the surpising and unexpected changes to the relationship between video games and artificial intelligence with a focus on the last five years of explosive research progress.  AI has changed from hand-coded programs that follow human-designed tactics to machine-learned models that learn their own tactics and video games are providing the means for researchers to develop math and tools that outperform most AIs ever created and sometimes even the very best humans.  We'll discuss research challenges, research milestones, significant breakthrough applications, and some advice and resources for anyone who wants to get into AI as a researcher, game developer, engineer, or even just hobbyist, at each step using the relationship between games and AI as context.

name: Jam Clinic Bandaoke Presents: Rap-aoke!
description: Continuing the tradition of Bandaoke, the Jam Clinic is offering for your Sunday hangover enjoyment a Bandaoke spin-off: RAPAOKE! It's all of the fun of Bandaoke with an emphasis on rap and hip-hop. Showcase your knowledge and love of rap lyrics and rapping by grabbing a mic while our live band provides the beats. Audience participation is highly suggested for singers, MCs, and instrumentalists of all stripes.

name: American Ninja Warrior: Gamer Strong!
description: Hear from athletes from NBC's popular show American Ninja Warrior! Learn about the history and what it is like to apply / compete on the show. Learn about the video game music that was used on the original show in Japan and what the athletes like to listen to while training / competing.

name: Where have all the heroes gone?
description: An exploration on the morality of gameplay, this panel describes how cultural individualism and postmodern relativism have impacted game communities and heroic representations in entertainment media. Heroism, as a concept, is rooted in community service and individual sacrifice, which has become an anathema in today’s “you do you” cultural ethic. How has that relativistic self-oriented ethos transformed our notions of heroes in both video games and tabletop gaming? Join us as we explore the ethics of game characters and the trends of heroism in recent game worlds.

name: Together We Ride (Again) - A History and Celebration of Fire Emblem
description:
In 1990, Nintendo released a game called Fire Emblem. After years of highs and lows, more than 30 years later, Fire Emblem has finally come into its own as one of Nintendo’s top-tier franchises.

Join us as we celebrate and discuss the rise, fall and return of Fire Emblem, from the early Japan-only SNES titles Americans are only now discovering, how a pair of Smash Bros fighters finally saw the US exposed to the series. We'll talk about the near death of the franchise before Fire Emblem: Awakening saved (or ruined?) the series, to the release of Fire Emblem: Three Houses as one of the Switch’s killer apps. And where does the franchise go from here?

We’ll dig into just what makes the franchise special, such as mechanics like permadeath, how it works as a work of high fantasy, how big a role “shipping” has played in the series’ success (and why that’s realistic for a military game), and how a cult series grew to become beloved by fans, gamers and cosplayers the world over. 

There will be prize giveaways, so grab your sword and brush up your support levels, as we celebrate three decades of Fire Emblem!
